title: Where We're at with Vaccines and Treatments for COVID-19
author: Shawn Radcliffe
description: Scientists around the world are working on a number of vaccines and treatments for COVID-19.
cleaned_text: - Scientists around the world have developed treatments and vaccines for the coronavirus disease known as [COVID-19](/health-news/coronavirus-live-updates). - Several companies are working on antiviral drugs, some of which are already in use against other illnesses, to treat people who have COVID-19. - At the moment, three vaccines that are used as a preventive measure against the disease are being distributed in the United States. With confirmed [COVID-19](/health-news/coronavirus-live-updates) cases in the United States surpassing [60 million](https://gisanddata.maps.arcgis.com/apps/opsdashboard/index.html#/bda7594740fd40299423467b48e9ecf6) and continuing to grow, scientists have spent the two years developing vaccines and treatments to slow the pandemic and lessen the disease's damage. On Oct. 22, the [Food and Drug Administration (FDA)](https://www.fda.gov/drugs/drug-safety-and-availability/fdas-approval-veklury-remdesivir-treatment-covid-19-science-safety-and-effectiveness) The agency has also issued [emergency use authorizations (EUAs)](https://www.fda.gov/emergency-preparedness-and-response/mcm-legal-regulatory-and-policy-framework/emergency-use-authorization#coviddrugs) An EUA allows doctors to use these drugs to treat people even before the medications have gone through the formal FDA approval process. As we wait for additional treatments and the distribution of already approved vaccines, there are still [other tools](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/prevent-getting-sick/prevention.html) "Even though technological advances allow us to do certain things more quickly, we still have to rely on social distancing, contact tracing, self-isolation, and other measures," [Dr. Bruce Y. Lee](https://sph.cuny.edu/people/bruce-y-lee/), a professor at the CUNY Graduate School of Public Health & Health Policy, told Healthline. Vaccines are designed to protect people before they're exposed to a virus — in this case SARS-CoV-2. A vaccine basically [trains the immune system](https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/hcp/conversations/downloads/vacsafe-understand-color-office.pdf) Vaccines also protect the community by reducing the spread of disease among people. This protection is known as [herd, or community, immunity](https://www.historyofvaccines.org/content/herd-immunity-0). Here's a look at some of the ongoing COVID-19 vaccine projects: Moderna / National Institutes of Health. The company began testing its two-dose messenger RNA (mRNA) vaccine in March 2020 in a [phase 1 clinical trial](https://www.cbc.ca/news/health/coronavirus-vaccine-1.5499244), with [promising results](https://www.cnbc.com/2020/05/18/moderna-reports-positive-data-on-early-stage-coronavirus-vaccine-trial.html). In late July, Moderna began [phase 3 clinical trials](https://www.cnn.com/2020/07/27/health/coronavirus-vaccine-trial-begins-moderna-phase-3/index.html) of the vaccine. In late August, company officials [said](https://www.cnbc.com/2020/08/26/moderna-says-its-coronavirus-vaccine-shows-promising-results-in-small-trial-of-elderly-patients.html) preliminary phase 1 trial data showed that the vaccine elicited a promising immune response in 10 people between the ages of 56 and 70 as well as 10 people over age of 70. The company [announced](https://investors.modernatx.com/news-releases/news-release-details/moderna-completes-enrollment-phase-3-cove-study-mrna-vaccine) in late October that it had finished recruiting all 30,000 participants in the phase 3 trial. This included more than 7,000 people over the age of 65 and more than 5,000 younger people with chronic conditions that increase their risk of severe COVID-19. In early October, company officials [announced](https://www.cbsnews.com/news/covid-vaccine-spring-2021-moderna-ceo/) their vaccine won't be available for wide distribution until spring 2021. Later in the month, Moderna's CEO [told investors](https://www.cnbc.com/2020/10/29/coronavirus-moderna-says-it-is-actively-preparing-for-launch-of-vaccine.html) that the trial's data and safety monitoring board could start analyzing study data in November. In mid-November, Moderna officials [reported](/health-news/moderna-covid-19-vaccine-94-effective-in-early-results-why-we-need-more-info) that their vaccine had achieved an effective rate of 94 percent in initial phase 3 trial results. Experts said more testing and more information is needed. On November 30, Moderna officials [said](https://www.cnet.com/news/moderna-mrna-coronavirus-vaccine-filed-for-fda-emergency-approval/) they would apply to the FDA for its vaccine to be approved for emergency use. On December 18, the FDA [granted](https://www.fda.gov/emergency-preparedness-and-response/coronavirus-disease-2019-covid-19/moderna-covid-19-vaccine) [began shipping out](https://www.cbsnews.com/news/moderna-covid-vaccine-shipments-begin-united-states/) the product three days later. In May 2021, company officials [announced](https://investors.modernatx.com/news-releases/news-release-details/moderna-announces-teencove-study-its-covid-19-vaccine) their vaccine was shown to be effective in clinical trials against COVID-19 in children 12 to 17 years old. In early June, Moderna officials [asked](https://investors.modernatx.com/news-releases/news-release-details/moderna-files-emergency-use-authorization-its-covid-19-vaccine) the FDA to grant them emergency use authorization to administer their vaccine to children from 12 to 17 years old. In September, Moderna officials [said](https://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-news/moderna-developing-single-dose-booster-shot-covid-flu-n1278799) they are developing a combination booster shot for both COVID-19 and the flu. The single shot has yet to go through a clinical trial. In late September, the company also released [results](https://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMoa2113017?query=featured_home) of a phase 3 clinical trial that showed its COVID-19 did not lose any of its effectiveness 5 months after a second dose had been administered. In late October, company officials [reported](https://www.upi.com/Top_News/US/2021/10/25/moderna-covid-vaccine-children-6-11/5361635175798/) that their COVID-19 vaccine was safe and effective for children from 5 years to 11 years old. In mid-November, the FDA [granted](/health-news/fda-expected-to-ok-covid-19-boosters-for-all-vaccinated-adults) emergency use authorization for the Moderna vaccine to be used as a booster for people 18 years and older. In January 2022, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) [reduced](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/different-vaccines/Moderna.html) Pfizer / BioNTech / Fosun Pharma. Drugmaker Pfizer teamed German biotech company BioNTech Chinese drugmaker Fosun Pharma to develop a two-dose mRNA vaccine. In August 2020, company officials [said](https://www.usnews.com/news/health-news/articles/2020-08-12/pfizers-covid-vaccine-shows-robust-results-in-early-trial) the vaccine had produced a "robust" response in a phase 1/2 clinical trial. The company [launched](https://www.nytimes.com/2020/07/27/health/moderna-vaccine-covid.html) a phase 3 trial in late July, with a goal to recruit 30,000 people from the United States, Brazil, Argentina, and Germany. They later [announced](https://www.pfizer.com/news/press-release/press-release-detail/pfizer-and-biontech-propose-expansion-pivotal-covid-19) plans to increase this to 44,000 people. In October, the company said it received [approval](https://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2020/10/13/923248377/will-kids-get-a-covid-19-vaccine-pfizer-to-expand-trial-to-ages-12-and-up) to enroll children as young as 12 years in the trial — the first American trial to include this age group. As of late October, the trial had [enrolled](https://www.cnbc.com/2020/10/27/pfizers-late-stage-coronavirus-vaccine-trial-is-near-complete-enrollment-with-42000-volunteers.html) more than 42,000 people. At the time, the company had not yet [conducted](https://www.statnews.com/2020/10/27/no-news-on-pfizers-covid-19-vaccine-is-good-news-and-bad-news/) an interim analysis of the study data, which puts it behind its original goal of doing so by September. However, the company still [expects](https://www.cnbc.com/2020/10/27/pfizers-late-stage-coronavirus-vaccine-trial-is-near-complete-enrollment-with-42000-volunteers.html) to have enough data sometime in November to apply for emergency use authorization from the FDA. On November 9, the company [announced](https://www.pfizer.com/news/press-release/press-release-detail/pfizer-and-biontech-announce-vaccine-candidate-against) that its vaccine had been more than 90 percent effective in clinical trial participants. A few days later, company officials [announced](https://www.cnn.com/2020/11/20/health/pfizer-vaccine-eua-submission/index.html) they were applying for an emergency use authorization from the FDA for their vaccine. It was the first regulatory approval in the United States for a COVID-19 vaccine. The officials said the vaccine could be available to high-risk groups as early as mid-December. On December 8, the FDA [released](https://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-news/fda-pfizer-s-covid-19-vaccine-safe-effective-after-one-n1250337) documents that reported the Pfizer vaccine offers some protection after the first dose and nearly full protection after a second dose. On December 11, the FDA [granted ](https://www.fda.gov/emergency-preparedness-and-response/coronavirus-disease-2019-covid-19/pfizer-biontech-covid-19-vaccine#:~:text=On%20December%2011%2C%202020%2C%20the,years%20of%20age%20and%20older.) [started](https://www.wsj.com/articles/pfizer-biontech-covid-19-vaccines-are-prepped-for-shipment-11607792605) distributing the product two days later. In January 2021, company officials said a [study](https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/2021.01.27.427998v1) indicated their vaccine is only slightly less effective against the COVID-19 variant from South Africa. In mid-February, a [study](https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-israel-vaccine/israeli-study-finds-94-drop-in-symptomatic-covid-19-cases-with-pfizer-vaccine-idUSKBN2AE0Q2) from Israel reported a 94 percent decrease in symptomatic COVID-19 cases among people who received both doses of the Pfizer vaccine. That [study](https://www.thelancet.com/journals/lancet/article/PIIS0140-6736(21)00448-7/fulltext) In mid-February, Pfizer officials [announced](https://www.pfizer.com/news/press-release/press-release-detail/pfizer-and-biontech-submit-covid-19-vaccine-stability-data) that they believe their vaccine can be stored at regular freezer temperatures. In late February, a [study](https://www.gov.uk/government/news/first-real-world-uk-data-shows-pfizer-biontech-vaccine-provides-high-levels-of-protection-from-the-first-dose) from the United Kingdom reported that a single dose of the Pfizer vaccine can reduce the risk of contracting the novel coronavirus by 70 percent with an 85 percent reduction after two doses. In early March, a [study](https://www.jwatch.org/na53283/2021/03/03/pfizer-covid-19-mrna-vaccines-real-world-performance) out of Israel reported that the Pfizer vaccine was highly effective in preventing COVID-19 in people with a variety of conditions, including obesity, high blood pressure, and type 2 diabetes. In mid-March, company officials [released](https://www.pfizer.com/news/press-release/press-release-detail/real-world-evidence-confirms-high-effectiveness-pfizer) from clinical data from Israel, reporting their vaccine was 97 percent effective in preventing symptomatic disease from COVID-19. In mid-May, the FDA [granted ](/health-news/children-as-young-as-12-may-soon-have-access-to-covid-19-vaccine)emergency use authorization for the Pfizer vaccine to be administered to children 12 years to 15 years old. In early June, Pfizer officials [announced](https://www.yahoo.com/news/pfizer-start-large-study-test-125848995.html) they will begin testing their vaccine on children younger than 12. In late October, they [said](https://www.upi.com/Health_News/2021/10/22/pfizer-covid-vaccine-children-5-11/6841634910577/) the trial had shown their vaccine was safe and effective for children 5 years to 11 years old. The CDC has now [authorized](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/different-vaccines/Pfizer-BioNTech.html) In January 2022, Pfizer officials [announced](https://apnews.com/article/pfizer-covid-vaccine-omicron-study-63cc1e6ee7c9c23e8795ce9bbd448ce9) they had begun testing a reformulated vaccine designed for the Omicron variant on healthy adults. Johnson & Johnson. Drugmaker Johnson & Johnson [announced](https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-johnsonandjohnson/experimental-johnson-johnson-vaccine-protects-monkeys-in-a-single-dose-study-idUSKCN24V1EO) in late July 2020 that it had begun a phase 1/2 trial in people after their adenovirus vaccine had shown promising results when used in monkeys. In late September, the company [announced](https://www.usnews.com/news/health-news/articles/2020-09-23/johnson-johnson-starts-phase-three-trial-for-coronavirus-vaccine-candidate) it was starting a phase 3 trial of its one-dose vaccine with 60,000 participants. In mid-October, the company [announced](https://www.cnn.com/2020/10/12/health/johnson-coronavirus-vaccine-pause-bn/index.html) it was pausing this trial due to an "unexplained illness" with one of the participants. The company has since received permission to [restart](https://www.statnews.com/2020/10/23/covid-19-vaccine-trials-from-astrazeneca-johnson-johnson-to-restart/) the study. In mid-November, Johnson & Johnson officials [said](https://www.foxnews.com/health/johnson-johnson-expects-coronavirus-vaccine-to-be-ready-approval-feb-report) they expected their vaccine to be ready for FDA approval by February. In mid-January 2021, company officials [reported](https://www.jnj.com/johnson-johnson-covid-19-vaccine-candidate-interim-phase-1-2a-data-published-in-new-england-journal-of-medicine) that in early clinical trials nearly all participants developed an immune response from the vaccine. In addition, the response lasted for at least 71 days. In late January, company officials [announced](/health-news/johnson-johnsons-covid-19-vaccine-is-72-effective-overall-over-50-on-emerging-variants) that their vaccine was 66 percent effective overall and more than 50 percent effective against the new variants. In early February, Johnson & Johnson [requested](https://www.jnj.com/johnson-johnson-announces-submission-of-application-to-the-u-s-fda-for-emergency-use-authorization-of-its-investigational-single-shot-janssen-covid-19-vaccine-candidate) an emergency use authorization for its vaccine. FDA regulators will examine the data in the ensuing weeks because this is the first of the one-dose vaccines. An FDA advisory panel is scheduled to consider the company's request in late February. In late February, company officials [announced](https://docs.house.gov/meetings/IF/IF02/20210223/111226/HHRG-117-IF02-Wstate-NettlesR-20210223.PDF) they will be able to deliver 20 million doses of their vaccine by the end of March. In late February, the company [received](/health-news/fda-says-jj-1-dose-vaccine-offers-strong-protection-against-severe-covid-19) emergency use authorization from the FDA for its single-dose vaccine. In early March, the White House [announced](https://apnews.com/article/merck-help-make-johnson-johnson-vaccine-9ca6f1f4c502b095531926a53abe7262) that Merck will help Johnson & Johnson manufacture its vaccine so the company can hit production targets. In mid-September, company officials [announced](https://apnews.com/article/johnson-and-johnson-covid-booster-4f86b7f00d354c289af17503eeb50824?utm_medium=AP&utm_campaign=SocialFlow&utm_source=Twitter) that a booster dose of its COVID-19 vaccine produced a strong immune response in participants in a clinical trial. The boosters were given 2 months to 6 months after the initial vaccine dose. The CDC [recommends](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/different-vaccines/janssen.html) AstraZeneca / University of Oxford. A phase 1 [clinical trial](https://www.cbsnews.com/news/coronavirus-vaccine-covid-19-human-clinical-trial-oxford-england/) at the University of Oxford began in late April 2020. The vaccine is based on a chimpanzee adenovirus, which shuttles coronavirus proteins into cells. In August, AstraZeneca began phase 3 trials in Brazil, South Africa, and the [United States](https://www.nih.gov/news-events/news-releases/phase-3-clinical-testing-us-astrazeneca-covid-19-vaccine-candidate-begins) [halted](https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-astrazeneca-usa-ex/exclusive-astrazeneca-u-s-covid-19-vaccine-trial-may-resume-as-soon-as-this-week-sources-idUSKBN2752C5) in September when a study volunteer developed a rare spinal inflammatory disorder called transverse myelitis. The trials were restarted a week later in Brazil and the United Kingdom. In late October, the FDA [authorized](https://www.astrazeneca.com/content/astraz/media-centre/press-releases/2020/fda-authorises-restart-of-the-covid-19-azd1222-vaccine-us-phase-iii-trial.html) the U.S. trial to resume. In mid-November, company officials [said](https://www.cnbc.com/2020/11/19/oxford-covid-vaccine-prompts-immune-response-among-all-adults-study.html) their vaccine had produced a strong immune response in a clinical trial that involved people over the age of 70. Data released on December 8 [indicated ](https://www.statnews.com/2020/12/08/detailed-data-on-astrazeneca-oxford-covid-19-vaccine-show-it-has-moderate-efficacy/)that the vaccine was safe but only about 70 percent effective. In early February 2021, company officials [announced](https://www.astrazeneca.com/media-centre/press-releases/2021/covid-19-vaccine-astrazeneca-confirms-protection-against-severe-disease-hospitalisation-and-death-in-the-primary-analysis-of-phase-iii-trials.html) that phase 3 clinical trial results showed that their vaccine was 82 percent effective after 12 weeks. They added that the vaccine was 100 percent effective in preventing severe disease, hospitalization, and death. They also noted that the vaccine achieved up to a 67 percent efficacy in preventing disease transmission. A few days later, South Africa officials [suspended plans](https://apnews.com/article/coronavirus-pandemic-africa-south-africa-oxford-europe-a157e08e9c6f36e124a9005b0dc5fa00) to inoculate their front-line healthcare workers because clinical trials indicated the AstraZeneca vaccine wasn't effective in preventing mild to moderate illness with the COVID-19 variant now dominant in that country. In mid-February, the World Health Organization [approved](https://www.who.int/news/item/15-02-2021-who-lists-two-additional-covid-19-vaccines-for-emergency-use-and-covax-roll-out) Novavax. This company [received](https://ir.novavax.com/news-releases/news-release-details/novavax-receive-388-million-funding-cepi-covid-19-vaccine) up to $388 million in funding in spring 2020 from the Coalition for Epidemic Preparedness Innovations (CEPI), a group that has funded COVID-19 vaccine development. The vaccine is made by attaching virus proteins to microscopic particles. In August, Novavax [launched](https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT04533399) a phase 2 trial in South Africa. A month later, the company [began](https://www.nytimes.com/2020/09/24/health/covid-19-vaccine-novavax.html) a phase 3 trial in the United Kingdom. It [plans](https://ir.novavax.com/news-releases/news-release-details/novavax-provides-phase-3-covid-19-vaccine-clinical-development) to start another phase 3 trial in the United States by the end of November. In late January 2021, company officials [announced](/health-news/novavax-covid-19-vaccine-90-effective-60-against-south-african-variant) their vaccine was 90 percent effective overall and 60 percent effective against the South African variant. Antivirals are drugs that are used for treating viral infections. Some antivirals target specific viruses, while others work against a number of viruses. These drugs can work in different ways such as preventing the virus from entering host cells, replicating, or releasing viral particles to infect other cells. In June 2021, White House officials [announced](https://apnews.com/article/anthony-fauci-united-states-infectious-diseases-coronavirus-pandemic-health-d9cfa18e561f3e58b2ae39e77353ab01) they will spend $3 billion this year on developing antiviral pills to treat COVID-19 symptoms. They said the new medications could be ready by the end of this year and could possibly be used to treat other pandemic viruses in the future. Here are some of antivirals being eyed as treatments for COVID-19. Many of these have been approved for other conditions or have been tested on other viruses. Remdesivir (brand name Veklury). Developed a [decade](https://www.statnews.com/2020/03/16/remdesivir-surges-ahead-against-coronavirus/) ago, remdesivir failed in clinical trials against Ebola in 2014. But it was found to be generally safe in people. [Research](https://www.jbc.org/content/early/2020/02/24/jbc.AC120.013056) with MERS, a disease caused by a different coronavirus, showed that the drug blocked the virus from replicating. In April 2020, drugmaker Gilead Sciences [announced](https://www.usnews.com/news/health-news/articles/2020-04-29/gilead-sciences-says-potential-coronavirus-treatment-remdesivir-shows-promise-in-study) that preliminary data from a trial of remdesivir overseen by the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID) had "met its primary endpoint." Based on these results, the FDA [issued an order](https://www.fda.gov/media/137564/download) In August, the agency [broadened](https://www.fda.gov/news-events/press-announcements/covid-19-update-fda-broadens-emergency-use-authorization-veklury-remdesivir-include-all-hospitalized) The results of a phase 3 trial published in October in the [New England Journal of Medicine](https://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMoa2007764) showed that remdesivir shortened the hospital stay of COVID-19 patients by about 5 days. People taking remdesivir also had a lower risk of dying compared to those who had been given an inactive control substance. On Oct. 22, the FDA [approved](https://www.fda.gov/drugs/drug-safety-and-availability/fdas-approval-veklury-remdesivir-treatment-covid-19-science-safety-and-effectiveness) Not all clinical trials have found that remdesivir is effective. A [study](https://www.thelancet.com/journals/lancet/article/PIIS0140-6736(20)31022-9/fulltext?utm_campaign=tlpr&utm_source=hs_email&utm_medium=email&utm_content=87146813&_hsenc=p2ANqtz-90BF_3ACwFC3R-No8zZYhpJRBScMqQSIi5IFSQB15O7x_GPsLLexPHy2il7LFFW5-304hHGomPoHpKu3O955OWPjhO2g&_hsmi=87146813) Preliminary results from a [World Health Organization trial](https://www.medrxiv.org/content/10.1101/2020.10.15.20209817v1) released in October found that remdesivir had little effect on how long people stayed in the hospital and no effect on their risk of dying. Remdesivir is also being tested in many [COVID-19 clinical trials](https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/results?cond=COVID-19&term=remdesivir&cntry=&state=&city=&dist=) around the world, including in combination with other drugs such as [interferon beta-1a](https://www.nih.gov/news-events/news-releases/nih-clinical-trial-testing-remdesivir-plus-interferon-beta-1a-covid-19-treatment-begins) [highly concentrated solution of antibodies](https://www.nih.gov/news-events/news-releases/nih-clinical-trial-testing-hyperimmune-intravenous-immunoglobulin-plus-remdesivir-treat-covid-19-begins) In mid-September, officials at Eli Lilly [announced](https://apnews.com/989eadbb02c845f3fcfe58321eeeca00) that in early stage trials their anti-inflammatory drug baricitinib when added to remdesivir can shorten hospital stays by 1 day for people with COVID-19. Olumiant, which is the name baricitinib is sold under, is already used to treat rheumatoid arthritis and other conditions that involve overactive immune systems. The drug is also being [tested in children](https://www.gilead.com/news-and-press/company-statements/gilead-sciences-statement-on-clinical-trial-of-remdesivir-in-pediatric-patients) with moderate to severe COVID-19. In mid-November, FDA officials [announced](https://www.fda.gov/news-events/press-announcements/coronavirus-covid-19-update-fda-authorizes-drug-combination-treatment-covid-19) In mid-July 2021, a [study](https://www.upi.com/Health_News/2021/07/15/coronavirus-remdesivir-study/8251626356176/) concluded that remdesivir provided no clinical benefit to people hospitalized with COVID-19 and may have actually extended their stay in the hospital. Nonetheless, in January 2022, the FDA [expanded](https://www.gilead.com/news-and-press/press-room/press-releases/2022/1/fda-approves-veklury-remdesivir-for-the-treatment-of-nonhospitalized-patients-at-high-risk-for-covid19-disease-progression) the use of remdesivir to adults and children 12 and older with mild to moderate COVID-19 symptoms who have not yet been hospitalized. AT-527. This drug was developed by Boston biotech Atea Pharmaceuticals and is being developed in partnership with drugmaker Roche. Atea began a [phase 2 trial](https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT04396106?term=AT-527&draw=2&rank=2) in May, testing the drug in people hospitalized with moderate COVID-19. The company [plans](https://www.biopharmadive.com/news/roche-atea-coronavirus-antiviral-drug-deal/587530/) to test the drug next year outside the hospital setting, and test to see if the drug can work in people recently exposed to the coronavirus. EIDD-2801. This drug was created by scientists at a nonprofit biotech company owned by Emory University. Research in mice has shown that it can [reduce replication](https://stm.sciencemag.org/content/12/541/eabb5883) Pharmaceutical company Merck and Ridgeback Biotherapeutics LP signed an [agreement](https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20200526005229/en/) in May to develop this drug. A [phase 1 trial](https://cen.acs.org/pharmaceuticals/drug-development/emerging-antiviral-takes-aim-COVID-19/98/web/2020/05) of this drug began in April in the United Kingdom, followed in July by a [phase 2 trial](https://www.pharmaceutical-business-review.com/news/ridgeback-eidd-2801-covid-19-phase-2/). Unlike remdesivir, EIDD-2801 can be taken orally, which would make it available to a larger number of people. Favipiravir (brand name Avigan). This drug, which is manufactured by the Japanese company Fujifilm Toyama Chemical Co., Ltd., is approved in some countries outside the United States to treat influenza. Japan, where the medication is made, is [sending the drug to 43 countries](https://www.cnbc.com/2020/05/04/fujifilms-flu-drug-favipiravir-sent-to-43-nations-for-covid-19-trials.html) for clinical trial testing in people with mild or moderate COVID-19. [Canadian researchers](https://globalnews.ca/news/7075744/canadian-researchers-test-antiviral-drug-coronavirus-covid-19-outbreaks-nursing-homes/) are testing to see whether the drug can help fight outbreaks in long-term care homes. In September, Fujifilm released the results of a [phase 3 trial](https://www.fujifilm.com/jp/en/news/hq/5451) that began in March. In mid-June, the National Institutes of Health [halted its clinical trial](https://www.nih.gov/news-events/news-releases/nih-halts-clinical-trial-hydroxychloroquine) In late June, British officials [announced](https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-hydroxychloroquine/global-covid-19-prevention-trial-of-hydroxychloroquine-to-resume-idUSKBN2410SW) they would restart a global clinical trial on hydroxychloroquine and chloroquine. In late July, scientists in Brazil [announced](https://www.cnn.com/2020/07/23/health/hydroxychloroquine-covid-brazil-study/index.html) that hydroxychloroquine given alone or with other drugs didn't improve the condition of people hospitalized with mild to moderate COVID-19. In late September, researchers at the University of Pennsylvania [reported](https://www.pennmedicine.org/news/news-releases/2020/september/hydroxychloroquine-no-more-effective-than-placebo-in-preventing-covid19) that hydroxychloroquine was no more effective in preventing the contraction of the new coronavirus in people who took the drug as opposed to those who didn't. In early March 2021, the a panel of experts from the WHO [stated](https://www.bmj.com/content/372/bmj.n526) - Phase 1. The drug is given to a small number of healthy people and people with a disease to look for side effects and figure out the best dose. - Phase 2. The drug is given to several hundred people who have the disease, looking to see whether it works and if there are any side effects that weren't caught during the initial testing. - Phase 3. In this large-scale trial, the drug is given to several hundred or even up to 3,000 people. A similar group of people take a placebo, or inactive compound. The trial is usually randomized and can take 1 to 4 years. This stage provides the best evidence of how the drug works and the most common side effects. - Phase 4. Drugs that are approved for use undergo continued monitoring to make sure there are no other side effects, especially serious or long-term ones.
